Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision on H&C grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentation was present but overemphasized
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Application records, family circumstances, best interests of children
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Exemption from inadmissibility based on H&C factors
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer's disproportionate focus on misrepresentation
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to declare dependants initially
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Family reunification, best interests of children, integration in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under Section 25
Crimes.Application_Factor: Misrepresentation as a factor, not determinative
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for redetermination by another officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False or incomplete declaration in immigration application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose dependants in immigration application
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-disclosure of dependants in sponsorship application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Sponsor failed to declare wife and children upon arrival
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Excluded from family class due to non-disclosure
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliant with residency requirements in Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of dependants in initial application
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Insufficient consideration of H&C factors in decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to assess H&C claims
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family ties, duration of stay, best interests of children
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of thorough analysis of humanitarian factors
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant credible despite sponsor's omission
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status based on H&C grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of H&C application by new officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under Section 25
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Overemphasis on misrepresentation, neglect of family reunification and children's best interests

Legal_Issue: Did the immigration officer reasonably assess humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds for exempting Duy from inadmissibility?
Outcome: H&C exemption denied
Credibility_Assessment: Officer focused heavily on mother's past misrepresentations
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds for exemption
Evidence_Ignored: Positive H&C factors such as family ties and living conditions

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose family member under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Violation_Type: Failure to disclose dependent family member
Application_Facts: Mother did not disclose son during her admission process
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer misconstrued evidence regarding living conditions
Outcome: Judicial review granted
Decision_Rationale: Undue focus on past misrepresentation, neglect of child’s best interests
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, Federal Court on review

Application_Facts: Son excluded due to non-disclosure, H&C exemption requested
Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly assess all H&C factors
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Positive H&C factors not genuinely assessed
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remitted
Relief_Sought: Exemption from inadmissibility under s. 25 IRPA
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child, holistic H&C assessment
Decision_Rationale: Decision unreasonably influenced by past misrepresentation
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, Federal Court on judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to declare dependent under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer's rejection of the applicant's humanitarian and compassionate grounds application was reasonable
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter remitted for reconsideration by a different officer
Evidence_Type: Evidence of educational opportunities, establishment in Canada, hardship in home country
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant not declared as dependent in 1995, leading to exclusion from family sponsorship
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Misapprehension of evidence regarding education and establishment
Application_Error: Failure to declare dependent at time of immigration
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applies to officer's discretion
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant’s educational goals, tuition constraints, limited time to establish due to visa restrictions
Application_Factor: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, best interests of the child, establishment in Canada
Document_Fraud: False omission in initial immigration application

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Application_Facts: Applicant applied for inland exemption on H&C grounds; rejected due to insufficient hardship and establishment evidence
Residency_Compliance: Applicant visited Canada but lacked permanent status
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider all H&C factors globally
Evidence_Used: Applicant's education plans, ties to Canada, conditions in St. Vincent
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient justification for conclusions on establishment and hardship
Outcome: Judicial review granted
Decision_Rationale: Misapprehension of evidence on education, underestimation of hardship abroad, inadequate reasoning on establishment

Dispute_Type: Administrative law dispute over immigration decision
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision on H&C grounds
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Court found misapprehension of evidence on education and establishment
Legal_Rule: H&C decisions reviewed on reasonableness standard; factors must be considered globally
Grounds_for_Claim: Errors in assessing education, establishment, and best interests of the child
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision set aside, remitted for reconsideration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's educational aspirations, lack of integration time due to visa limits
Legal_Framework: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of education, personal circumstances, country conditions
Outcome: Remanded for redetermination
Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA related to H&C considerations

Dispute_Type: Interpretation of humanitarian and compassionate grounds in inland exemption
Legal_Issue: Correct legal test for assessing H&C grounds
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Officer misinterpreted evidence on education and establishment
Legal_Rule: H&C factors must be assessed globally, best interests of child considered without rigid formulas
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapprehension of evidence, inadequate reasons for decision
Key_Evidence_Considered: University acceptance, tuition costs, duration of stay in Canada
Legal_Framework: Procedural fairness and reasonableness in immigration decisions
Evidence_Type: Academic records, financial constraints, personal declarations
Outcome: Case remitted for reconsideration by different officer
Legal_Provision: IRPR provisions on inland exemptions and H&C considerations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the visa officer's decision to deny permanent residence based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds reasonable?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's spouse did not disclose marriage prior to gaining permanent residency
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to disclose marital status before permanent residency
Crimes.Application_Error: Non-accompanying family member not examined at time of sponsorship
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under IRPR
Crimes.Application_Factor: Spouse not disclosed during initial application
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in visa application regarding marital status

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to disclose material information in immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's wife failed to disclose her marriage before becoming a permanent resident
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking permanent residence based on relationship
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to disclose marital status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of marriage prior to permanent residency
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Family member not examined at time of sponsorship
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of compelling humanitarian or compassionate reasons
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to nondisclosure
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn visa officer's decision via judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under Section 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No compelling humanitarian or compassionate grounds to exempt from regulatory bar

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Application_Facts: Applicant Viasna applied for permanent residence under family class sponsorship and humanitarian/compassionate grounds; officer speculated on applicant's motives; evidence of communication with Viasna was ignored; cultural factors misinterpreted as abandonment
Misrepresentation_Element: No finding of misrepresentation; issue centered on officer's interpretation
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review filed after exhaustion of appeal options; disputes over timing and standing resolved in favor of applicant
Evidence_Used: Communication records between applicant and sponsored family member
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer disregarded available evidence of ongoing communication
Reliance on conjecture rather than documented facts
Credibility_Assessment: Officer incorrectly assessed lack of contact as deliberate abandonment without supporting evidence
Decision_Outcome: Visa officer rejected application based on alleged non-compliance with family class requirements and insufficient humanitarian/compassionate grounds
Outcome: Court allowed judicial review, set aside the officer's decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under IRPA s.25(1)
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to speculative reasoning and failure to consider relevant evidence
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Program Manager erred in concluding insufficient humanitarian and compassionate grounds for exemption
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 25; section 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside, case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants concealed marriage and children
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Exclusion from family class due to non-disclosure during initial application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to consider family unification and best interests of children
Crimes.Application_Error: Non-disclosure of family members
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under s.25
Crimes.Application_Factor: Concealment of marital status and children
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Crimes.Legal_Standard: H&C exemption under s.25

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer made a reviewable error in assessing humanitarian and compassionate grounds, particularly considering the best interests of the child

Key_Factor_in_Determination: No unusual hardship demonstrated to justify exemption

Decision_Outcome: Denial of application under normal criteria; no reviewable error found

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer erred in concluding the marriage was not genuine and ignored relevant evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer identified minor discrepancies in interview answers
Evidence_Type: Medical records naming applicant as next of kin
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) grounds based on marriage to a Canadian citizen
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Substantial documentary evidence supporting marriage genuineness
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider highly relevant documentary evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Medical records with designation as next of kin
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of review is reasonableness under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Marriage to a Canadian citizen after failed refugee claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside; case remitted for redetermination by another officer

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer erred in concluding the marriage was not genuine and ignored relevant evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer focused on minor interview inconsistencies while disregarding objective proof of relationship
Evidence_Type: Medical records naming applicant as next of kin
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Exemption from visa requirements on humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to marriage
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of substantial documentary evidence confirming marital legitimacy
Crimes.Application_Error: Sole reliance on minor discrepancies without weighing contrary documentary evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Healthcare documents listing partner as emergency contact
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of review is reasonableness under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Marriage to a Canadian citizen following denial of refugee status
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed; remanded for reassessment by a different immigration officer

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in applying s. 25 of IRPA and adequately considering humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Sponsor's failure to disclose family members questioned, but remorse noted
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Application records, family relationship documents, statements of remorse
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refusal of sponsorship due to non-disclosure in original application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inadequate consideration of H&C factors, especially best interests of children
Crimes.Application_Error: Overemphasis on non-disclosure, failure to assess H&C factors holistically
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Positive H&C factors including family stability and children’s best interests
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Proper exercise of discretion under s. 25 IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Non-disclosure of family members in initial application
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No explicit fraud, but omission in disclosure

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose family members on immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer properly applied s. 25 IRPA and considered H&C factors despite non-disclosure
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 117(9)(d) of Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR), s. 25 IRPA
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Sponsor lacked full credibility due to omission, but demonstrated remorse
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application forms, family documentation, sponsorship package
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Ineligibility to sponsor due to failure to disclose family members initially
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer's disproportionate focus on non-disclosure over H&C considerations
Crimes.Application_Error: Fettering of discretion by overemphasizing non-disclosure
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Balanced evaluation of H&C factors under s. 25 IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Family ties, stability, and best interests of children
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Discretionary exemption under s. 25 IRPA for H&C grounds
Crimes.Application_Factor: Omission of family members in original immigration application
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Omission rather than falsification, but constitutes misrepresentation by concealment

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration requirements
Legal_Issue: Did the officer err in assessing the humanitarian and compassionate grounds for the applicants' exemption from immigration requirements?
Evidence_Assessment: Risk factors, establishment, family ties, support for elderly parents
Credibility_Factor: No credibility issue raised, no procedural fairness breach
Legal_Rule: Officer must assess hardship based on unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate factors; decision must be justifiable, transparent, and intelligible
Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds for exemption
Outcome_on_Merits: Officer's decision was reasonable and within acceptable outcomes
Key_Evidence_Considered: Family ties, establishment in Canada, risk factors, support system for parents
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), H&C provisions
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of H&C application denial
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, no questions certified

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of IRPA (visitor compliance with conditions)
Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visas, refugee status denied, applied for H&C relief
Claimant_Status: Former temporary residents, failed refugee claimants
Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain legal status after visa expiry
Evidence_Used: Evidence of establishment, hardship claims, risk factors
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Decision_Outcome: H&C application denied, judicial review dismissed
Outcome: Officer’s decision upheld by Federal Court
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship test
Decision_Rationale: Lack of sufficient evidence to demonstrate exceptional hardship or compelling reasons for exemption

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections related to stay and removal
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's H&C application failed to consider personalized risks; removal would lead to potential imprisonment and economic hardship
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to assess individualized risks in H&C application
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence of integration in Canada, risk of imprisonment upon return
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not properly assess personal risk factors
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Integration into Canadian society and risk of irreparable harm justify stay

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, claimed risks upon return and strong ties to Canada
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: H&C application denied without adequate assessment of personal circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Length of stay, integration, family ties, risk of imprisonment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Personalized risks not assessed by decision maker
Crimes.Outcome: Allowed to remain until H&C decision is judicially reviewed
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Irreparable harm likely and balance of convenience favors applicant due to integration
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency, Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Accuracy and honesty in immigration status declaration
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 40
Crimes.Outcome: Stay of removal granted pending review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about credibility due to prior misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentation of military evasion, economic circumstances, community integration
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds despite inadmissibility
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Integration in Canada and risk of imprisonment
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider individualized risks in H&C assessment
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Totality of circumstances for H&C consideration
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Personalized risk factors such as military evasion consequences
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of residence, family ties, employment
Crimes.Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose HIV status upon entry and visa renewals
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsections 44(1) and 44(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to disclose HIV-positive status during visa renewals
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to disclose material information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Preparation of inadmissibility report and referral for admissibility hearing
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa application records, criminal record, disclosure history
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure on visa renewals
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative due to non-disclosure
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review to challenge inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Severity of non-disclosure and criminal negligence conviction outweighed humanitarian factors

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of reasons and reasonableness of inadmissibility report under Section 44
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction record and sentencing documents considered
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 44 allows inadmissibility reports for serious criminality
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged inadequate reasons and unreasonable decision
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 44

Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual(s) harmed due to negligent conduct
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged

Governing_Law: Paragraph 18.1(4)(d) of the Federal Courts Act
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of forced marriage by uncles in Kenya
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility, suspicious delay in filing
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Legal_Standard: Perverse, capricious, or made without regard to evidence
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Legal_Provision_Violated: Failure to assess under country of asylum class criteria
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 115(2) - Country of Asylum Class
Application_Facts: Applicants are Hazara from Afghanistan; claimed discrimination and risk due to ongoing conflict
Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to consider country of asylum class eligibility
Evidence_Used: Conditions in Afghanistan, Hazara persecution, conflict-related risks
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of assessment on serious personal effects from conflict
Decision_Outcome: Application refused based solely on Convention refugee criteria
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application under correct legal framework
Legal_Standard_Applied: Convention refugee and country of asylum class criteria
Decision_Rationale: Officer committed a reviewable error by not evaluating country of asylum class eligibility despite evidence of serious personal effects from conflict

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Visa refusal based on credibility and admissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can section 11 of the Act be a basis for visa refusal without specific inadmissibility findings?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 11(1) and 40(1)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's inconsistent statements and discrepancies with family testimonies undermined credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Inconsistent oral statements, conflicting family testimonies
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Doubt about non-inadmissibility due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent statements affecting credibility
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide consistent and credible information
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Section 11(1) satisfaction of non-inadmissibility
Crimes.Application_Factor: Credibility and consistency of applicant’s statements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to answer truthfully as per section 16(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Untruthful and evasive responses during interview

Crimes.Application_Facts: Inconsistent and vague responses regarding work history, family displacement, and LTTE involvement
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over judicial review
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible and consistent testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant not credible due to inconsistencies and evasiveness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to answer truthfully under section 16(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to meet burden of proving non-inadmissibility due to lack of credibility

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of PRRA officer's assessment and need for interview on credibility
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 113(a); Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 167
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, case referred for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer made adverse credibility findings based on past misrepresentations without interview
Crimes.Evidence_Type: New evidence of changed country conditions
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk due to perceived LTTE links and changed country conditions
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to hold interview despite serious credibility concerns
Crimes.Application_Error: Did not convene interview despite implicit credibility findings
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for evidence, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential credibility issues requiring oral clarification
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false passport and prior false statements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Preventing Return as a Crime under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with removal order despite risk claims

Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant subject to removal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Prior use of false documents and inconsistent claims
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of interview despite credibility concerns
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: PRRA officer’s authority to assess new evidence

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient new evidence to support risk claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility based on prior misrepresentations
Crimes.Outcome: Referred for redetermination by another officer
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal, positive PRRA decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to address credibility through required procedures

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of negative PRRA decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in PRRA assessment and necessity of interview

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Perceived affiliation with LTTE and deteriorating conditions in home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer's failure to conduct interview despite credibility concerns
Crimes.Application_Error: Assessed credibility without providing opportunity for oral explanation
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of evidentiary assessment, correctness of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Need for clarification on credibility through interview
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to ensure procedural fairness in high-stakes decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of document fraud and inconsistent claims

Dispute_Type: Visa denial based on medical inadmissibility of non-accompanying family member
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of visa denial under IRPA and Regulations regarding medical inadmissibility and adoption genuineness
Governing_Law: IRPA s.42(a), Regulations s.23, Regulations s.4
Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; case remitted for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Adoption by aunt deemed not genuine
Evidence_Type: Medical records, custody arrangements, adoption documentation
Legal_Provision: IRPA s.42(a) – inadmissibility due to health grounds; Regulations s.23 – exemption for valid custody; Regulations s.4 – bad faith adoptions
Basis_of_Claim: Medical inadmissibility of non-accompanying child (Dong Jun)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to consider applicability of s.23 and inadequate analysis of adoption legality
Application_Error: Failure to apply regulatory exemption under s.23; insufficient assessment of adoption
Evidence_Ignored: Potential validity of custody arrangement under s.23
Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness in administrative decision-making
Application_Factor: Non-accompanying disabled child excluded from application
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of Immigration and Refugee Protection Act relating to procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Second applicant likely present but not interviewed; officer rejected plausible evidence without considering illiteracy; persecution claims under Convention refugee class not explored
Procedural_Issue: Failure to interview all applicants and dependents; failure to provide opportunity to respond to concerns
Evidence_Used: Applicants' submitted evidence on credibility and persecution claims
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Illiteracy not considered; lack of exploration into persecution claims
Credibility_Assessment: Officer rejected evidence without sufficient basis; credibility concerns raised without proper evaluation
Decision_Outcome: Application refused due to alleged lack of credibility
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decisions set aside
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application by appropriate authority
Decision_Rationale: Officer breached procedural fairness by failing to interview and consider key factors such as illiteracy and persecution claims

Application_Facts: Applicant faced alleged threats from Sri Lankan authorities and Karuna group
Evidence_Used: Threats by Sri Lankan authorities and Karuna group
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Generalized risks rather than Convention grounds, inconsistent evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues found by the Board
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities, more than a mere possibility of persecution or torture
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was reasonable based on credibility concerns and lack of evidence linking threats to Convention grounds

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer erred in finding misrepresentation under paragraph 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant initially misrepresented employment history but clarified during interview; clarification deemed insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation of material facts regarding employment history
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Misrepresentation was adopted by applicant before correction and could induce administrative error
Crimes.Application_Error: False declaration of employment experience
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of officer's interpretation and application of law
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation that induces or could induce an error in the administration of the Act
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing and nature of correction during interview
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court (implied from judicial review context)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer erred in finding misrepresentation under paragraph 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant falsely claimed work experience as a computer programmer and admitted falsity during interview
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False claim of professional work experience
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Misrepresentation was made and relied upon until corrected during interview
Crimes.Application_Error: Falsely claiming work experience as a computer programmer
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation that induces or could induce an error in the administration of the Act
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and timing of admission during interview
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible for two years
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court (implied from judicial review context)

Violation_Type: Excessive demand on health or social services
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 38(1)(c) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant is an HIV-positive skilled worker who provided a detailed plan for managing HIV-related expenses, including free medication from a charity and employer-provided health coverage.
Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for permanent residence
Procedural_Issue: Visa officer failed to consider the applicant's submissions regarding financial plan for medical costs
Evidence_Used: Medical diagnosis, prognosis, applicant's financial and health coverage plan
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not assess the sustainability or adequacy of the proposed funding plan
Decision_Outcome: Applicant deemed inadmissible on medical grounds
Outcome: Federal Court found decision unreasonable and allowed judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different visa officer
Decision_Rationale: The officer focused solely on the medical diagnosis and prognosis without considering the applicant’s evidence of private health coverage and external support, which could prevent excessive demand on public services.
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer at Canadian visa office

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose previous visa denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration Officer erred in assessing the applicant's ties to India
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, paragraph 20(1)(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned applicant's intent to return to India
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 20(1)(b), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient demonstration of ties to home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Perceived lack of strong ties to India despite evidence
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under section 72 of the Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider all relevant evidence of ties to India
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Higher salary in Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration Officer erred in concluding insufficient ties to India
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, paragraph 20(1)(b)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision quashed and remanded
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer doubted applicant's intention to leave Canada after authorized stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 20(1)(b), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Lack of sufficient ties to home country (India)
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Focus on higher Canadian salary while ignoring countervailing ties
Crimes.Application_Error: Overemphasis on one factor (salary) and disregard of other evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Higher salary in Canada

Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate personalized risk upon removal
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 72(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk upon return to India based on speculative assertions about irregular travel documents and airport scrutiny without supporting evidence
Claimant_Status: Applicant in PRRA process following refugee claim rejection
Procedural_Issue: PRRA used to re-litigate previous decision rather than present new evidence of changed circumstances
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of significant new evidence showing changed country conditions or personal risk
Credibility_Assessment: Claims found speculative and lacking probative value
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certification of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in assessing officer's conclusion
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision was reasonable as applicant failed to show significant change in circumstances or personalized risk

Legal_Issue: Is the IAD's decision that the marriage is not genuine based on implausibility findings legally valid?
Governing_Law: Tribunal can make adverse credibility findings if the claimant's story is implausible, but only in clear cases where facts are outside reasonable expectations; cultural context must be considered.
Outcome: Decision overturned, case remanded for reconsideration by a different panel.
Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility findings based on implausibility
Evidence_Type: Marriage evidence, cultural context of arranged marriage in India
Basis_of_Claim: Arranged marriage challenged by IAD due to perceived lack of genuineness based on cultural assumptions
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to properly consider cultural context and apply correct standards for arranged marriages in India
Application_Error: IAD failed to analyze evidence in light of traditional Indian marriage standards
Assessment_Standard: Plausibility standard requiring clear implausibility and consideration of cultural norms
Evidence_Ignored: Evidence related to cultural practices regarding arranged marriages in India
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard of review; duty to consider cultural context in credibility assessments
Application_Factor: Cultural differences in marital behavior and expectations
Decision_Outcome: IAD decision set aside due to reviewable error

Application_Facts: Applicants' PRRA application was brief due to anticipation of permanent residence approval; after refusal of permanent residence, they did not update their PRRA submission; decision made 10 months later without new novel evidence
Residency_Compliance: Not in compliance – failed to update application despite opportunity
Procedural_Issue: Failure to notify applicants of reactivation of PRRA application and opportunity to submit supplementary information
Evidence_Used: Original PRRA application, no new 'novel' evidence presented
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of updated submissions from applicants despite ample opportunity
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Declaration that procedural fairness was violated
Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of fairness under administrative law
Decision_Rationale: No breach of fairness found as applicants had ample opportunity to update their PRRA application but failed to do so

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer breached the duty of fairness or erred in law in denying exemption under s. 114(2)
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found insufficient evidence that marriage was genuine and that return to Northern Ireland posed risks
Evidence_Type: Interview records, risk-related documents, marriage evidence
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds for exemption
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of sufficient evidence supporting genuine marriage and personal risk
Decision_Maker: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court
Assessment_Standard: Duty of fairness; minimal procedural obligations
Legal_Standard: Error in law, bad faith, improper principles

Application_Facts: Saad's citizenship application was approved by a citizenship judge; the Minister appealed, arguing inadequate reasoning.
Residency_Compliance: The judge did not specify which residence test was used or why it was met.
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate reasons provided by the citizenship judge, leading to an unclear and unintelligible decision.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to clarify the basis for meeting the residence requirement.
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application initially approved by judge.
Outcome: Appeal allowed; decision set aside and remitted for redetermination.
Relief_Sought: Minister sought to overturn the approval of Saad's citizenship application.
Decision_Rationale: Reasons were inadequate because they failed to justify or explain which residence test was applied and how it was satisfied.

Outcome: Claim dismissed by Refugee Protection Division
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding based on implausibility and inconsistencies
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, timeline discrepancies, country condition information
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution due to Shia affiliation and activism in Pakistan
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to claim asylum in the U.S., inconsistent timeline, perceived implausibility of targeting
Application_Error: Selective use of evidence, reliance on assumptions
Evidence_Ignored: Explanations for not claiming asylum in the U.S., context of transit through the U.S.
Application_Factor: Credibility, plausibility, consistency with known facts
Decision_Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration by a differently constituted panel

Application_Facts: Mrs. Mindich was absent from Canada multiple times, totaling 618 days present within the four-year period preceding her application
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum physical presence; only 618 days in Canada over four years
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge inadequately analyzed 'centralized mode of life' and connection to Canada
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, ties to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of applicant's attachment to Canada
Outcome: Mrs. Mindich did not meet residency requirement; decision set aside
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application; 'centralized mode of life' test
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge failed to properly assess Mrs. Mindich's connection to Canada under the correct legal framework

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Brown served 17 months pre-trial; Crown suggested 2:1 credit; sentencing judge imposed 1 additional day in jail
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident or Protected Person (implied by deportation context)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether pre-sentence incarceration counts toward the 'term of imprisonment'
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD's jurisdiction to hear appeal based on length of sentence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear judicial intent to grant 2:1 credit for pre-trial custody
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD erred in assuming automatic 2:1 credit
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order based on serious criminality
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Pre-trial custody may count if considered part of punishment, but no automatic doubling without judicial intent

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Robbery with potential use of weapon (contextual link)
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of imitation firearm (linked to co-charge)
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Credit for pre-trial custody considered but not clearly applied
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (indictable offence with potential for lengthy sentence)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to violent nature and firearm involvement
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential for reoffending or threat to community
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient for conviction but ambiguity in sentencing details
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible but incomplete regarding credit application
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Inclusion and calculation of pre-trial custody toward two-year threshold under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Using an imitation firearm during the commission of an offence
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of imitation firearm increasing danger and severity
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No explicit mention of harm caused or intent to fire
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to weapon involvement
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Ambiguity in whether pre-trial custody counted toward two-year threshold under IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code – Using an imitation firearm (s. 88 or s. 344(a)(ii))

Legal_Issue: Whether the LCBO's use of 'Millennium' as an official mark conflicts with the applicant's trademark rights
Evidence_Assessment: LCBO provided insufficient evidence to support prior adoption and use of 'Millennium' as an official mark
Decision_Outcome: Court allowed the application, declaring the LCBO's official mark ineffective
Burden_of_Proof: On LCBO to prove prior adoption and use of the official mark
Credibility_Factor: Court found LCBO's claim unconvincing due to lack of substantiation
Legal_Rule: Official marks under subparagraph 9(1)(n)(iii) take precedence over trademarks if properly adopted and used
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness in judicial review of Registrar's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Conflict between LCBO's official mark and applicant's registered trademark
Outcome_on_Merits: Applicant succeeded; LCBO's official mark declared ineffective
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence (or lack thereof) of LCBO's adoption and use of 'Millennium' as an official mark
Defendant_Response: LCBO claimed prior adoption and use of 'Millennium' as an official mark
Evidence_Type: Documentary and procedural evidence of use and adoption
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside the Registrar's decision to publish the official mark
Outcome: Application allowed; official mark deemed ineffective
Authority: Registrar of Trademarks, Canadian Intellectual Property Office

Crimes.Crime_Name: Erroneous Finding of Fact in Immigration Decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer based her decision on an erroneous finding of fact without considering material evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to mention or analyze applicants' experience letters
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate unreasonableness or breach of fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Credibility concerns raised but not properly addressed
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Administrative fact-finding must be reasonable; officers must acknowledge and analyze relevant evidence
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous finding of fact, failure to consider relevant evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicants' experience letters were not considered
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and principles of administrative law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No response indicating consideration of submitted evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Set aside decision and remit for redetermination
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, matter remitted to a different officer

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer ignored relevant evidence affecting reasonableness and fairness

Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged document veracity concerns not communicated

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer breached the duty of fairness by not notifying applicants of concerns about document veracity
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Applications denied due to credibility and knowledge concerns
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to show procedural unfairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Concerns about authenticity of experience letters

Crimes.Defendant_Response: No request for additional evidence or clarification sent
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, matter remitted for redetermination

Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness and incorrect assessment of applicant's chosen occupation
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to assess reliability concerns with documentary evidence
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility, but officer must follow fair process
Credibility_Factor: Documents deemed unreliable without prior notice to applicant
Legal_Rule: Visa officers must assess applicants under their chosen occupation and provide opportunity to respond to document concerns
Grounds_for_Claim: Breach of procedural fairness, failure to assess NOC 4162, lack of notice on document concerns
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; decision found procedurally unfair
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, administrative fairness principles
Defendant_Response: No response detailed; decision made ex parte by visa officer
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remitted to different visa officer
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Regulations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in dismissing the applicants' refugee claims due to inadequate evidence of state protection and misinterpretation of IRPA
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants provided evidence of past trauma; RPD found efforts to seek state protection insufficient
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Evidence of past trauma, police response, attempts to access state protection

Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for evidence assessment, correctness for legal interpretation and bias
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation in border documentation or claim process

Crimes.Victim_Status: Ms. Garcia Rivadeneyra, adult female survivor
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Multiple incidents including sexual assault and robbery

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Occurred alongside robbery, sexual assault, and threats

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claims of misconduct not substantiated with sufficient evidence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Bias allegations reviewed on correctness; other findings on reasonableness

Crimes.Defendant_Response: RPD maintained adequacy of state protection and absence of bias

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Incidents occurred in conjunction with sexual assault and threats
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No use of weapons specifically mentioned; no injuries detailed

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient due to lack of reporting and follow-up
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, possible medical or police records
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible but actions inconsistent with claimed fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found truthful but not proactive in seeking help

Dispute_Type: Immigration status and eligibility for permanent residence
Legal_Issue: Whether legal adoption under foreign law automatically establishes a parent-child relationship for Canadian immigration purposes
Evidence_Assessment: Tribunal assessed legality of Philippine adoption but did not assess existence of genuine parent-child relationship
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal's decision set aside; case remanded for redetermination
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate genuine parent-child relationship
Legal_Rule: Adoption must comply with foreign law and create a genuine parent-child relationship under Canadian immigration law
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of 'no objection' letter, insufficient humanitarian grounds, misinterpretation of regulations
Outcome_on_Merits: Application initially allowed by tribunal, then overturned on review
Key_Evidence_Considered: Legality of Philippine adoption, absence of factual parent-child relationship analysis
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, specifically adoption provisions in Immigration Regulations
Defendant_Response: Minister challenged tribunal's decision on grounds of legal error
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (adoption documents), procedural compliance records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside tribunal's decision
Outcome: Tribunal's decision set aside, case referred back to Immigration and Refugee Board
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether 'people smuggling' under IRPA s.37(1)(b) can be defined using s.117 of IRPA rather than an international instrument
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.37(1)(b)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant claimed invitee status due to ship escort; court found interception in Canadian waters negates such status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural fairness or legal error
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of evidence supporting invitee status
Crimes.Legal_Rule: IRPA s.37(1)(b) allows inadmissibility for people smuggling without criminality finding
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenged inadmissibility based on alleged people smuggling
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Location of interception (Canadian waters), nature of vessel approach
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued invitee status and need for criminality finding

Crimes.Crime_Name: No finding of criminality required for inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is a finding of criminality necessary for determining inadmissibility under section 37(1)(b) of IRPA?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant argued criminality must be established; court found statutory language clear
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show statutory misinterpretation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 37(1)(b) does not require a criminality finding for inadmissibility
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Claim that criminality must be proven for inadmissibility
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Text of IRPA, comparison with s.36(1)/(2)
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court, citing Justice Simon Noël’s decision in IMM-4761-11

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on smuggling allegations
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether definition of 'people smuggling' should follow international instruments or domestic law
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Materials reviewed by court, arguments heard
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency / Immigration Division
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged facilitation of unauthorized entry into Canada
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: By vessel intercepted in Canadian waters
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No criminal finding made; irrelevant under s.37(1)(b)
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Interception within Canadian jurisdiction, lack of invitee status, statutory definition under s.117

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Delegate breached procedural fairness by denying cross-examination of Detective Fernandes

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed, remanded for reconsideration by different delegate
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in immigration context based on false statements about criminal involvement

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Deportation based on alleged serious criminality

Dispute_Type: Trademark Infringement and Opposition to Registration
Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant's trademarks are confusingly similar to the respondent's existing trademarks
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Trademarks Opposition Board decision to Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Substantial overlap in targeted consumer bases and product categories; significant recognition of Chinese characters among respondent’s clientele
Decision_Outcome: Appeals dismissed; registration of applicant's trademarks refused
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to prove lack of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Recognition of Chinese characters in the marketplace by relevant consumers
Legal_Rule: A trademark is confusing if its use would likely cause the public to infer that the goods or services come from the same source
Standard_of_Review: Likelihood of confusion under the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Opposition based on similarity of marks leading to potential consumer confusion
Outcome_on_Merits: Respondent succeeded; applicant's marks deemed too similar to established trademarks
Key_Evidence_Considered: Consumer base overlap, product category similarity, linguistic recognition (Chinese characters)
Defendant_Response: Opposed registration on grounds of likelihood of confusion
Evidence_Type: Market perception evidence, trademark usage data, consumer recognition studies
Outcome: Registration refused due to likelihood of confusion

Crimes.Crime_Name: Illegal use of electricity or gas
Driving with more than 80 mgs. of alcohol in blood
Possession for the purpose of trafficking
False or misleading statements in tax returns
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant claimed ignorance and reliance on third-party advice; CRA found no extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's claim of misunderstanding not deemed credible or sufficient
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 220(3.1) allows waiver only under extraordinary circumstances beyond taxpayer's control
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for waiver of penalties and interest due to alleged misunderstanding
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of compliance history, lack of due diligence, no evidence of extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Framework: ITA and CRA policy guidelines (e.g., IC 92-2)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA denied request based on absence of extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and declarative evidence regarding tax remittance practices
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Waiver of penalties and interest under ITA Subsection 220(3.1)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to meet statutory payroll obligations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to remit CPP contributions, citing ignorance and third-party advice
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Taxpayer/employer subject to payroll deduction requirements
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Reliance on third-party advice without verification
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of extraordinary circumstances or due diligence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims not considered credible or sufficient
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Ignorance of law and third-party errors do not constitute extraordinary circumstances

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to withhold Canada Pension Plan contributions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant cited ignorance and third-party advice; CRA found no extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show undue hardship or extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's misunderstanding not accepted as valid defense
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Waiver allowed only under extraordinary circumstances or undue hardship
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for relief based on claimed ignorance and reliance on advisor
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Compliance history, due diligence, nature of error
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA maintained denial due to lack of qualifying circumstances

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to remit Canada Pension Plan contributions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to remit, paid penalties, claimed ignorance and third-party error
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On taxpayer to demonstrate eligibility for relief
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claims of misunderstanding not supported by evidence of due diligence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 220(3.1) requires extraordinary circumstances or hardship for relief
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for waiver due to non-compliance from misinterpretation of obligations
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Payment history, compliance record, explanation for failure
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA denied request citing lack of extraordinary circumstances
